nodes.bodyText: Shall we remove this new line?
you dont need catch and re-throw the same exception here. Having the throws in the method signature would suffice
Shall we rename this function to be more meaningful? Something like initProjectByTemplate
@hevayo should we throw an error if the project name contains characters that are not allowed, or continue with a warning?
Since we decided to throw an error during the code review, we can continue with this.
Shall we address the AddCommand changes in a seperate PR since this doesnt have all the required changes?

 package org.ballerinalang.packerina.cmd;

nodes.bodyText: We already have this constant declared as MODULES_ROOT at L45
This method doesn't seem to have any usages. If so, shall we remove it?

New Command without any args should default to the "main" template. Therefore, we should add an assertion to verify that the main.bal file exists.
Misleading function name. The test implementation verifies the "main" template but the function name is related to testing the "service" template.
Lets fix this and add tests to test the "service" and "lib" templates
Let's add a test case for the "lib" template as well

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,67 @@
+NAME
+       ballerina-init - Create a new Ballerina project inside current directory.
+
+SYNOPSIS
+       ballerina init
+       ballerina init <package-name>
+
+
+DESCRIPTION
+       Init initializes a Ballerina project inside the current directory.
+
+       A project is a set of logically related Ballerina modules that share
+       the same 'Ballerina.toml', 'Ballerina.lock' files and the 'target'
+       directory.
+
+       The project directory will have the following structure.
+            .
+            ├── Ballerina.toml
+            ├── Ballerina.lock
+            ├── main.bal
+            └── tests
+                ├── main_test.bal
+                ├── resources
+            ├── resources
+            └── Module.md
+            └── Package.md
+
+       Any directory becomes a Ballerina project if that directory has a
+       'Ballerina.toml' file. It contains the organization name and the

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,67 @@
+NAME
+       ballerina-init - Create a new Ballerina project inside current directory.
+
+SYNOPSIS
+       ballerina init
+       ballerina init <package-name>
+
+
+DESCRIPTION
+       Init initializes a Ballerina project inside the current directory.
+
+       A project is a set of logically related Ballerina modules that share
+       the same 'Ballerina.toml', 'Ballerina.lock' files and the 'target'
+       directory.
+
+       The project directory will have the following structure.
+            .
+            ├── Ballerina.toml
+            ├── Ballerina.lock
+            ├── main.bal
+            └── tests
+                ├── main_test.bal
+                ├── resources
+            ├── resources
+            └── Module.md
+            └── Package.md
+
+       Any directory becomes a Ballerina project if that directory has a
+       'Ballerina.toml' file. It contains the organization name and the
+       version. It also enables dependency management across the project.
+
+       The 'modules' directory contains Ballerina modules. Use
+       'ballerina add <module-name>' command to create modules.
+
+       Both 'target' directory and 'Ballerina.lock' file are created during
+       the build process. The 'target' is the output directory that contains
+       build artifacts.
+
+       The 'Ballerina.lock' file will specify versions of the dependent modules.
+       If the 'Ballerina.lock' file exists the 'ballerina build' command will
+       use the specified versions instead of fetching the latest
+       versions of modules.
+
+       A template can also be specified when initialising the new project.

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,67 @@
+NAME
+       ballerina-init - Create a new Ballerina project inside current directory.
+
+SYNOPSIS
+       ballerina init
+       ballerina init <package-name>
+
+
+DESCRIPTION
+       Init initializes a Ballerina project inside the current directory.
+
+       A project is a set of logically related Ballerina modules that share
+       the same 'Ballerina.toml', 'Ballerina.lock' files and the 'target'
+       directory.
+
+       The project directory will have the following structure.
+            .
+            ├── Ballerina.toml
+            ├── Ballerina.lock
+            ├── main.bal
+            └── tests
+                ├── main_test.bal
+                ├── resources
+            ├── resources
+            └── Module.md
+            └── Package.md
+
+       Any directory becomes a Ballerina project if that directory has a
+       'Ballerina.toml' file. It contains the organization name and the
+       version. It also enables dependency management across the project.
+
+       The 'modules' directory contains Ballerina modules. Use
+       'ballerina add <module-name>' command to create modules.
+
+       Both 'target' directory and 'Ballerina.lock' file are created during
+       the build process. The 'target' is the output directory that contains
+       build artifacts.
+
+       The 'Ballerina.lock' file will specify versions of the dependent modules.
+       If the 'Ballerina.lock' file exists the 'ballerina build' command will
+       use the specified versions instead of fetching the latest
+       versions of modules.
+
+       A template can also be specified when initialising the new project.
+       If a template is not specified, this command initialise a project with
+       Ballerina.toml file inside the current directory.
+
+      There are three built-in templates named:
+        1. main
+        2. service
+        3. lib
+
+OPTIONS
+     -t <template-name>, --template <template-name>
+         Create a package using a predefined template.
+
+     -l, --list
+         List built-in templates.
+
+
+EXAMPLES
+     Initialise a package with a 'main' template.
+        $ ballerina init
